quiz.title: Client-Side Routing Quiz
quiz.description:
It's time to check your knowledge! Use this quiz to create a custom study guide. Note any answers that were marked incorrect, so you can study the relevant material and try this quiz again.

If you don't know the answer to a question, please do not guess. Instead, select "I don't know". It's OK not to know everything and to admit when we're unsure.

questions.question_text:
Which hook gives us the ability to programmatically navigate the user to a new
page in our application?

answers.comments: Correct! We use the useHistory hook to access React Router's history object, which lets us navigate users to new pages with methods such as .push().
answers.comments_html: Correct! We use the useHistory hook to access React Router's history object, which lets us navigate users to new pages with methods such as .push().

answers.comments: We use the useParams hook to get the dynamic params from the URL.
answers.comments_html: We use the useParams hook to get the dynamic params from the URL.

answers.comments: We use the useState hook to return a stateful value, and a function to update it.
answers.comments_html: We use the useState hook to return a stateful value, and a function to update it.

questions.question_text:
______ is the process of handling all the routing logic with JavaScript,
without making any additional GET requests for some new HTML document.
questions.incorrect_comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: Match each React Router component with the correct description.
questions.incorrect_comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

answers.right: Renders the first child <Route> or <Redirect> that matches the current location.
Provides declarative, accessible navigation around your application.
Responsible for rendering a component when its path matches the current URL.

matches.text: Renders the first child <Route> or <Redirect> that matches the current location.
Provides declarative, accessible navigation around your application.
Responsible for rendering a component when its path matches the current URL.

questions.question_text:
Server-side routing happens when the route is handled internally by the
JavaScript that is loaded on the page.

answers.comments: Server-side routing happens when a route requests a new page or data from the server. Client-side routing happens when the route is handled internally by the JavaScript that is loaded on the page.
answers.comments_html:
Server-side routing happens when a route requests a new page or data from the server.

Client-side routing happens when the route is handled internally by the JavaScript that is loaded on the page.

answers.comments: Correct! Server-side routing happens when a route requests a new page or data from the server. Client-side routing happens when the route is handled internally by the JavaScript that is loaded on the page.
answers.comments_html:
Correct! Server-side routing happens when a route requests a new page or data from the server.

Client-side routing happens when the route is handled internally by the JavaScript that is loaded on the page.

questions.question_text:
The ______ component's responsibility is to render a component when its
path matches the current URL.
questions.incorrect_comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: The _____ hook returns an object of key/value pairs of URL parameters.
questions.incorrect_comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: The useParams hook allows a component to access data based on the dynamic portion of the URL, such as /dogs/:id.

We use ______ to change the browser's URL and show the user a new page in
our application without making the user click on a link.

answers.comments: Correct! Programmatic Navigation is useful when you want a user to be shown a new page on your site following some action other than clicking a link. For example, we could use programmatic navigation to show a new page after they've submitted a form.
answers.comments_html:
Correct! Programmatic Navigation is useful when you want a user to be shown a
new page on your site following some action other than clicking a link. For
example, we could use programmatic navigation to show a new page after they've
submitted a form.

answers.comments: We use dynamic routing when the router is using data from a different route based on the current state.
answers.comments_html:
We use dynamic routing when the router is using data from a different route
based on the current state.

answers.comments: Client-side routing happens when the route is handled internally by the JavaScript that is loaded on the page.
answers.comments_html:
Client-side routing happens when the route is handled internally by the
JavaScript that is loaded on the page.

questions.question_text: What are the benefits of client-side routing? (Select all that apply)

answers.text: Speed when navigating within the application.
answers.comments: Correct! With client-side routing, we don't have to wait for a new HTML document and all its associated content to load whenever a user clicks a link to visit another page on our site.
answers.comments_html:
Correct! With client-side routing, we don't have to wait for a new HTML
document and all its associated content to load whenever a user clicks a link
to visit another page on our site.

answers.comments: Correct! Client-side routing makes it easier to programmatically navigate a user to a new page on our side.
answers.comments_html:
Correct! Client-side routing makes it easier to programmatically navigate a
user to a new page on our side.

answers.text: Conditionally rendering components based on the URL.
answers.comments: Correct! Client-side routing makes it easier access data from the URL using JavaScript, so we can conditionally render different components based on the URL.
answers.comments_html:
Correct! Client-side routing makes it easier access data from the URL using
JavaScript, so we can conditionally render different components based on the
URL.

answers.text: Easier for analytical tools to track page views.
answers.comments: Because there are typically less requests made to the server in client-side routing, this can make it more challenging to set up analytic tools to track data (like page views) from our routes.
answers.comments_html:
Because there are typically less requests made to the server in client-side
routing, this can make it more challenging to set up analytic tools to track
data (like page views) from our routes.

answers.comments: Client-side routing does have a longer initial page load, because it loads everything at the beginning, as opposed to when a route is requested.
answers.comments_html:
Client-side routing does have a longer initial page load, because it loads
everything at the beginning, as opposed to when a route is requested.

questions.question_text: Which hook should we use to access the dynamic pieces of a URL?

answers.comments: Correct! The useParams hook returns a key/value pair of URL parameters based on our Route components.
answers.comments_html: Correct! The useParams hook returns a key/value pair of URL parameters based on our <Route> components.

answers.comments: The useHistory hook gives you access to the history instance that you may use for programmatic navigation.
answers.comments_html: The useHistory hook gives you access to the history instance that you may use for programmatic navigation.

answers.comments: We use the useState hook to return a stateful value, and a function to update it.
answers.comments_html: We use the useState hook to return a stateful value, and a function to update it.
